name: Cholent (Hamin)
name_origin: The Hebrew name 'Hamin' (חמין) is derived from Mishnaic Hebrew, originating from the Semitic root H-M-M (ח-מ-ם), meaning 'to be hot' or 'warm'. It literally translates to 'hot things' or 'warmth', referring to the rabbinic injunction to keep food warm for the Sabbath. The English/Yiddish name 'Cholent', while Ashkenazi, is widely accepted to derive from Old French 'chault' (hot) and 'lent' (slow), reflecting the cooking method. In the specific context of Djerban and Tunisian Jewry, while 'Hamin' is the religious term, the dish is historically known as 'Tfina' or 'Dafina'.
description: A traditional slow-cooked Sabbath stew featuring meat, beans, barley, and potatoes. While 'Cholent' is the Ashkenazi term, this recipe follows the universal Jewish tradition of a heavy stew cooked overnight for lunch on Shabbat.
cultural_context: Although the source uses the Yiddish term 'Cholent', this style of slow-cooked dish is known as 'Hamin' in Hebrew or 'Skhina'/'Dafina' in North African traditions. The addition of eggs (Haminados) is typical of Sephardic and North African versions.
vegan_adaptation_notes: Replace meat with root vegetables (sweet potatoes, carrots) or plant-based meat chunks. Omit eggs.

ingredients.name: Seitan chunks (wheat gluten)
ingredients.notes: or use large chunks of portobello mushrooms

steps.instruction: Heat oil in a large heavy-bottomed pot. Add the diced onions and fry patiently until they turn a dark golden brown. This provides the base color for the stew.
steps.tips: Do not burn the onions, but get them very dark for flavor.

steps.instruction: Add the meat chunks to the pot and sear on all sides until browned.
Add the potatoes, soaked beans (white and brown), and barley to the pot.
Fill the pot with water until all ingredients are covered.
Add the spices: paprika, black pepper, garlic powder, salt, and the maple syrup (or honey).
Bring the pot to a boil. Once boiling, reduce heat to low.
Gently place the whole eggs (in their shells) on top of the stew.
Cover and simmer on low heat for about 1.5 hours. For traditional Sabbath preparation, transfer to a hot plate (blech) or slow cooker to cook overnight until lunch the next day.
steps.tips: The flavors deepen significantly with overnight cooking.

name_etymology.notes: While the cookbook uses the pan-Jewish terms 'Hamin' and 'Cholent', the authentic Djerban/Tunisian Judeo-Arabic term is 'Tfina' (from the Arabic root D-F-N, 'to bury', referring to burying the pot in the embers of the communal oven/Tabouna).

alternative_names.name: Tfina / Dafina
alternative_names.notes: The specific Judeo-Arabic term for the Sabbath stew in Tunisia and Morocco; literally 'buried'.

alternative_names.name: Skhina
alternative_names.notes: Common in Morocco, literally meaning 'The Hot One' (equivalent to Hamin).

alternative_names.name: Pkaïla
alternative_names.notes: A specific, popular Tunisian variety of Hamin/Tfina made with spinach and white beans.

alternative_names.name: Harissa
alternative_names.notes: A wheat-berry based Sabbath stew common in Tunisia and Libya (distinct from the spice paste).

similar_dishes.name: Herisseh / Hareesa
similar_dishes.key_difference: Texture is beaten into a porridge/paste; not exclusively for Sabbath.

similar_dishes.name: Cassoulet
similar_dishes.similarity: Slow-cooked casserole with meat and white beans.
similar_dishes.key_difference: Contains pork; cooked in an open vessel to form a crust rather than sealed/buried.

similar_dishes.name: Tangia
similar_dishes.similarity: Meat stew slow-cooked in a clay urn in the ashes of a hammam.
similar_dishes.key_difference: Usually lamb and spices only (no grains/beans); traditionally a 'bachelor's dish' rather than a family Sabbath meal.

intro_paragraph: Cholent, called Hamin in Hebrew, is the Ashkenazi slow-cooked Shabbat stew. It is the Eastern European equivalent to Moroccan Adafina and Tunisian Tfina. The name 'Cholent' derives from the Old French 'chalant' meaning 'warm'. All three dishes share the same purpose: food kept warm overnight for the Shabbat morning meal.

vegan_substitutions.notes: Provides the chewy, savory texture essential for the stew
Mimics the visual and structural element of whole eggs (Haminados)
